concept_description.description: A coded list of reasons for patient appointment or visit to a health provider.
Other Reason for patient appointment
Reason for visit
ART Refill
This is to check if visit is on tb refill
This is a check to see if a person is being switched or substituted in care for example on their first appointment date
A question to check if persons appointment is a refill or not.
This is a check to see if a person is being initiated in care for example on their first appointment date
A combination of ZIDOVUDINE, LAMIVUDINE and DOLUTEGRAVIR
A combination of ABACAVIR, LAMIVUDINE and DOLUTEGRAVIR
A combination of TENOFOVIR, LAMIVUDINE and DOLUTEGRAVIR
This regimen is a has been suggested in the new treatment guidelines for Uganda
Number of ART pills left at the next visit
Coded list of past medical history problems but not procedures which are coded under Past Surgical History.
Tumors or cancer of the uterine cervix.
Enrollment into HIV Care Transfer in from
Current ARV regimen
Previous ART regimen
Prison EMR Concept Id for classification
Time duration between true labor and birth. Numeric portion to be used with duration units concept (1732)
The concept is to distinguish the stage of labor, the first stage of labor is the time of the onset of true labor until the cervix is completely dilated at 10 cm
Konsep ini untuk membedakan tahap dalam persalinan, tahap pertama persalinan adalah waktu awal persalinan dimana serviks melebar sampai 10 cm
The concept is to distinguish the stages of labor, the second stage of labor is the period after the cervix is dilated at 10 cm until the baby is delivered
Konsep ini untuk membedakan tahap dalam persalinan, tahap kedua persalinan adalah periode setelah serviks melebar ke 10 cm sampai bayi dilahirkan

Either symptomatic diabetes or impaired glucose tolerance induced by pregnancy but resolved at the end of pregnancy. It does not include previously diagnosed diabetics who become pregnant (PREGNANCY IN DIABETES).
How many times did she undergo cesarean section for delivering baby?
Weight of extracted placenta after delivery in kgs
Pay category. Don't quite know what this means yet, but first seen on the pediatric return visit form.
Pay category noted on encounter form. Coverage through PEPFAR funds or philanthropic donations through the Indiana University.
Pay category noted on encounter form. Members of the hospital staff whose benefits include health care and for whom the hospital should be paying for care.
Pay category noted on encounter form. A program through the Kenyan Government which provides drugs at a discounted rate to patients.
Pay category noted on encounter form. Staff of the MTCT-plus program for whom care should be provided through the MTCT-plus grant.
Pay category noted on encounter form. Funding for care is provided through a research grant.
Pay category noted on encounter form. A category for patients who can't self pay but have not yet been assigned to a payer source.
Pay category noted on encounter form.
Patient pays for their own evaluation and related treatment. Used as an answer for pay category
A generic, descriptive answer which is a handwritten, non-coded response to a question.
Question on encounter form. Defines the pay category of a patient for each visit. Patient can currently have only one of these categories, but this can and will change in the future.
The number of children a woman has delivered.
Birth of child at or near term (39.5-40.5 weeks)
Date of last CD4 count done for the patient as reported (rather than recorded as test result).
Booster vaccination against diptheria and tetanus (IM) used in pediatric patients.
(بچوں کے لیے ڈفتھیریا اور ٹٹنس کی بوسٹر ویکسین (ائی ایم
Vaccination against measles (IM).
Booster vaccination against tetanus.
Vaccination given for diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis infections
Vaccination given for hepatitis B.
Generic descriptive answer.
DTP+H. Influenza+Hep B Vaccine
Vaccine given for HIB.
A generic, descriptive answer which is a handwritten, non-coded response to a question.
Vaccine given for Yellow Fever.
Death of the young developing in utero.
Expulsion of the products of conception before the completion of gestation without deliberate interference.
Pentavalent childhood immunization
Combination of measles and rubella (German measles) vaccine
Date in which a mother delivers her child, or pregnancy ends.
Congenital malformations of organs or parts.
APGAR score taken from neonate 1 minute after birth (0-10).
APGAR score taken from neonate 5 minutes after birth (0-10).
Whether birth resulted in alive, fresh stillborn or macerated stillborn baby.
Neonate started breastfeeding within one hour of birth.
The height the patient had at birth.
The head circumference the patient had at birth.
Drugs that are ordered at a given patient encounter. Typically used in a set with other medication information.
The full date of a vaccination
Question as to whether the procedure (immunization, etc.) was actually received by the patient.
The number from the register book or registry. Usually taken from a paper registry. Use encounter type to differentiate different classes of serial numbers.
The class or type of facility to which the patient was referred.
A child's or baby's weight in kilograms.
Admission number for the integrated Nutrition register

Dilation (dilatation) and curettage refers to the dilation (opening) of the cervix and surgical removal of the contents of the uterus. It is a therapeutic gynecological procedure as well as a rarely used method of first trimester abortion. It is commonly referred to as a D&C. REF: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dilation_and_curettage
A family planning method.
Condition of vaginal bleeding with or without pain in early pregnancy which may presage an abortion.

A placenta which develops in the lower uterine segment, in the zone of dilatation, so that it covers or adjoins the internal os. Painless hemorrhage in the last trimester, particularly during the eighth month, is the most common symptom. (Dorland, 27th ed)
Onset of convulsions or coma in a previously diagnosed pre-eclamptic patient.

Development of hypertension with proteinuria, edema, or both, due to pregnancy or the influence of a recent pregnancy. It occurs after the 20th week of gestation, but it may develop before this time in the presence of trophoblastic disease.
Premature separation of the normally implanted placenta.
A pathological condition caused by lack of oxygen, manifested in impending or actual cessation of life.
The name of the facility or provider where the patient was referred TO.
Age of baby in weeks
Referring clininc
Place patient has been referred to for farther care provision.
Referal of babies on PNC Visit
Referal of babies on PNC Visit
Revisit ANC clients, who were tested for HIV on a previous ANC visit with known HIV Negative Status
Hepatitis B Test Results
Third ANC visit
First ANC visit
Second ANC visit
Fourth ANC visit
Fifth ANC visit
Sixth ANC visit
Seventh ANC visit
Eighth ANC visit
Ninth ANC visit
Tenth ANC visit
The program which deals with the health issues of mother and children.
DSDM Model in community where patients pick drugs from a distribution point in community set by their health centre
DSDM Model with client lead groups with rotation drug pickup by client them selves and distribution.
DSDM for stable or unstable clients who need peer support
DSDM Model for patients who only pick drugs at the health centre.
This is a DSDM model for patients that need extra management at the health centre
Physician, doctor or clinical officer
Trained nurse personnel
Semi-trained birth assistant, unspecified if private or government funded.
CAPTION: During the health clinic/post visit(s), who attended to the patient?
A qualitative assessment of the child's weight given his/her age. Generally, growth chart is used to identify the nutritional status.
Tuberculosis of the lungs.
Tuberculosis of the lungs.
Resistance to at least both isoniazid and rifampicin
Free text for non-coded clinical impressions.
treatment of the disease successfully terminated the problem. Can be generalized to all the diseases as a outcome of the treatment.
Which phase of the tuberculosis treatment the patient is on?
phase/stage of the tuberculosis treatment
Type of tuberculosis patient based on previous treatment.
Qualifier value for the quantity.
A simple boolean used to track coinfection among mdr-tb patients. Used by the mdr-tb module.
General finding of a contaminated specimen.
Convenience set of TB drugs
Structured entries from free text clinician notes
Whether the patient is taking co-trimoxazole as a prophylactic treatment against Pneumocystis pneumonia, which occurs in patients with immunodeficiency.
Standard deviation that a child's weight is from the median weight of a child at the same AGE in the reference data (WHO chart)
Healthcare professionals who practice in pharmacy, the field of health sciences focusing on safe and effective medication use.
Convenient set to capture medication dispensed
Nutritional status classification on child based on the index of Height for Age Status between -3 and -2 z-scores.
Klasifikasi status gizi pada anak berdasarkan indeks Tinggi/Umur untuk z-score antara -2 dan -3 SD.
Nutritional status classification on child based on the index of Height for Age Status less than -3 z-scores.
Klasifikasi status gizi pada anak berdasarkan indeks Tinggi/Umur untuk z-score kurang dari -3 SD
Question to capture when CTX prophylaxis was started.

Resistance to rifampicin detected using phenotypic or genotypic methods, with or without resistance to other anti-TB drugs. It includes any resistance to rifampicin, in the form of mono-resistance, poly-resistance, MDR or XDR.
Resistance to more than one first-line anti-TB drug, other than both isoniazid and rifampicin
When was the HIV test performed?
Descriptive term: not precisely defined, determinable, or established.
For children: Nutritional status classification on child based on the index of Height for Age Status more than 2 z-scores.
Increase in body weight beyond skeletal and physical standards as the result of an excessive accumulation of fat in the body. More than two times the ideal weight is considered OBESITY, MORBID.
Difficult or labored breathing.
The forcible expulsion of the contents of the stomach through the mouth.

The lack of sufficient energy or protein to meet the body's metabolic demands, as a result of either an inadequate dietary intake of protein, intake of poor quality dietary protein, increased demands due to disease, or increased nutrient losses.

The lack of sufficient energy or protein to meet the body's metabolic demands, as a result of either an inadequate dietary intake of protein, intake of poor quality dietary protein, increased demands due to disease, or increased nutrient losses.

Sleep hyperhidrosis, more commonly known as the night sweats, is the occurrence of excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis) during sleep. The sufferer may or may not also suffer from excessive perspiration while awake. Sleep hyperhidrosis may occur at any age, but is most commonly seen in early adulthood. ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Night_sweats

The lack of sufficient energy or protein to meet the body's metabolic demands, as a result of either an inadequate dietary intake of protein, intake of poor quality dietary protein, increased demands due to disease, or increased nutrient losses.

The lack of sufficient energy or protein to meet the body's metabolic demands, as a result of either an inadequate dietary intake of protein, intake of poor quality dietary protein, increased demands due to disease, or increased nutrient losses.
Clinical manifestation consisting of a physiopathological lack or loss of appetite accompanied by an aversion to food and the inability to eat.

Acidosis caused by accumulation of lactic acid more rapidly than it can be metabolized. It may occur spontaneously or in association with diseases such as diabetes mellitus, leukemia, or liver failure.
Acute hepatitis caused by true hepatotoxins such as Amanita phaloides toxin, carbon tetrachloride, yellow phosphorus, and a variety of drugs. (From Dorland, 28th ed)
Well appearance during general physical exam.
Bacterial colonies grown in the culture media
Result of the sensitivity testing.
Intermediate resistant to anti-tubercular drugs. Result of the sensitivity testing.
Result of the sensitivity testing.
Used to describe a concentration in a DST test. Maps to datatype double.
Injectable aminoglycoside used in drug-resistant TB treatment. Inhibits protein synthesis through disruption of ribosomal function. (Short name from WHO)

Reinforcement TB med with unclear efficacy. Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic used to treat pharyngitis, tonsillitis, acute maxillary sinusitis, acute bacterial exacerbation of chronic bronchitis, pneumonia (especially atypical pneumonias associated with Chlamydia pneumoniae or TWAR), skin and skin structure infections, and, in HIV and AIDS patients to prevent, and to treat, disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC). In addition, it is sometimes used to treat Legionellosis.
Phenazine derivative used in drug-resistant TB treatment. (Short name from WHO)
D-Alanine analog used in drug-resistant TB treatment. (Short name from WHO)
Anti-mycobaterial drug used to treat active tuberculosis. Always used with other antimycobacterial agents.
Isonicotinic acid derivative used in drug-resistant TB treatment. (Short name from WHO)
Fluoroquinolone used in drug-resistant TB treatment. (Short name from WHO)
A crystalline antibacterial compound (C6H7N3O) used in the treatment of tuberculosis.
Aminoglycoside used in drug-resistant TB treatment. (Short name from WHO)
Anti-folate used in drug-resistant TB treatment. (Short name from WHO)
Isonicotinic acid derivative used in drug-resistant TB treatment. (Short name Pto from WHO)
Antituberculosis agent used to treat patients with active tuberculosis, usually in combination with other agents.
A crystalline phenolic alcohol C8H11NO3 of the vitamin B6 group found especially in cereals and convertible in the body into pyridoxal and pyridoxamine.
Reinforcement TB med with unclear efficacy. Rifabutin is a bactericidal antibiotic drug primarily used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

Terizidone is a combination of two cycloserine molecules. It is an anti-tuberculous drug used in treating multidrug-resistant TB. TERIZIDONE is considered effective in the treatment of TB and may also be useful for the treatment of urinary tract infections including those due to TB. It is recommended for the treatment of MDR-TB patients in both the intensive and continuation phases. Oral bacteriostatic second-line TB med.
Type of health care facility designed to be the district hospital.
A thiosaemicarbazone that is used in association with other antimycobacterial agents in the initial and continuation phases of antituberculosis regimens
A basic polypeptide antibiotic (trade name Viocin) administered intramuscularly (along with other drugs) in the treatment of tuberculosis
The number of pills/tablets/bottles of medication dispensed
The strength of the medication if not part of selection
Length of time medication was taken for medication history. Use with duration units.
Resistance to any fluoroquinolone, and at least one of three second-line injectable drugs (capreomycin, kanamycin and amikacin), in addition to multidrug resistance

One of several skin tests to determine past or present tuberculosis infection. A purified protein derivative of the tubercle bacilli, called tuberculin, is introduced into the skin by scratch, puncture, or interdermal injection.
Descriptive term, classically described as having the appearance of millet seeds. Diffuse, granular lesions throughout lung fields often seen with tuberculosis.

One of several skin tests to determine past or present tuberculosis infection. A purified protein derivative of the tubercle bacilli, called tuberculin, is introduced into the skin by scratch, puncture, or interdermal injection.
Macroscopic, microscopic, microbiological and/or biochemical analysis of CSF
Result of PCR test determining MTB present with rifampin resistance
Result of PCR test for MTB showing no rifampin resistance
A generic answer to a question. Not valid or erroneous.
Result of PCR test determining MTB present with only unknown or indeterminate rifampin resistance
Examination of protein level in CSF in mg/dL
Measurement of glucose in CSF sample in mg/dL
Bacterial culture of CSF sample
Microscopic evaluation of CSF
Appearance of CSF on macroscopic evaluation
Cell count of CSF including total leukocyte count and differential count
Measurement of CSF pressure in mmHg.
This concept represents a general Gram staining technique for any specimens
Information was not collected because the question was not asked, patient not examined, or not otherwise assessed.
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Date when the Biopsy, Mantoux,CSF ,xray and gene Xpert tests were done
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test

Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Test result from a Sputum for Acid Fast Bacilli test
Date when the Biopsy, Mantoux,CSF ,xray and gene Xpert tests were done
TB Prophylaxis regimen including: Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide and Ethambutol
TB Prophylaxis regimen including: Rifampicin and Isoniazid
Telephone number to contact person.
The month after the start of treatment the test was taken. For example: M0, M2, M3, M5, END.
TB Medication Diagnosis Set
TB DST Result Set
TB Adverse Events Set
Next of Kin Village
Percentage Doses of ARVs Missed
New encounter with patient for purposes of reporting. Defined differently in different locales. Usually new episode of disease.
Test for rapid diagnosis of Malaria.
A qualitative assessment of the child's weight given his/her age. Generally, growth chart is used to identify the nutritional status.
Whether the patient consumes alcohol or not
A repeating field used to capture historical medication use.
Physical device for transporting patients in seated position.
Free text entry to record name of next of kin
Whether the patient uses tobacco or not. This includes any use of tobacco; smoking, chewing, snuff, etc.
What type of assistive device does the patient use?
Generic response to a question.
Descriptive term: not precisely defined, determinable, or established.
A general descriptive answer: a patient's health care provider.
For children: Nutritional status classification on child based on the index of Height for Age Status more than 2 z-scores.
Increase in body weight beyond skeletal and physical standards as the result of an excessive accumulation of fat in the body. More than two times the ideal weight is considered OBESITY, MORBID.

The lack of sufficient energy or protein to meet the body's metabolic demands, as a result of either an inadequate dietary intake of protein, intake of poor quality dietary protein, increased demands due to disease, or increased nutrient losses.

The lack of sufficient energy or protein to meet the body's metabolic demands, as a result of either an inadequate dietary intake of protein, intake of poor quality dietary protein, increased demands due to disease, or increased nutrient losses.

The lack of sufficient energy or protein to meet the body's metabolic demands, as a result of either an inadequate dietary intake of protein, intake of poor quality dietary protein, increased demands due to disease, or increased nutrient losses.

The lack of sufficient energy or protein to meet the body's metabolic demands, as a result of either an inadequate dietary intake of protein, intake of poor quality dietary protein, increased demands due to disease, or increased nutrient losses.
Currently, as an answer or qualifier for a question. At the current time, presently, etc.
In the past, as an answer to a question or qualifier such as historically...
Test result was positive for Falciparum malaria
Test result was positive for Vivax.
Test result was positive for both Falciparum and Vivax malaria
Nutritional status classification on child based on the index of Height for Age Status between -3 and -2 z-scores.
Klasifikasi status gizi pada anak berdasarkan indeks Tinggi/Umur untuk z-score antara -2 dan -3 SD.
Nutritional status classification on child based on the index of Height for Age Status less than -3 z-scores.
Klasifikasi status gizi pada anak berdasarkan indeks Tinggi/Umur untuk z-score kurang dari -3 SD
Information gathered on encounter forms which describes the date of a particular drug's institution. Most often "globbed" with another concept which describes the drug.
Information gathered on encounter forms which describes the date of a particular drug's discontinuance. Most often "globbed" with another concept which describes the drug.
Drugs that are ordered at a given patient encounter. Typically used in a set with other medication information.
The strength of the medication if not part of selection
The units which correspond to the numeric value entered for a duration
Describes a reason for stopping an order. Coded answer.
Question as part of medication history
Length of time medication was taken for medication history. Use with duration units.
This is a freetext field for general use. It should be tied to another concept as a child.
A diagnosis or problem for which a medication is or was prescribed
Frequency of medication prescribed
The amount of a medication to be taken in a given dose, for example, take 2 pills every four hours (2 is the quantity, pills are the form and every four hours is the frequency)
Adverse reaction to a drug (oral, parenteral, topical).
Patient unable to pay for treatment.
Failure of a therapy or treatment to achieve its end points.
Generic temporal answer to question.
Generic temporal answer to question.
Generic temporal answer to question.
Generic descriptive answer.
interval of duration
Interval of duration
A duration unit, 60 minutes = 1 hour.
Patient or client refusal of or resistance to medical, psychological, or psychiatric treatment. (APA, Thesaurus of Psychological Index Terms, 8th ed.)
treatment of the disease successfully terminated the problem. Can be generalized to all the diseases as a outcome of the treatment.
A qualifier term which can be used to differentiate a numeric entry. For example, a duration could be a number + duration unit (number of occurrences).
Unit of time, 1/60 of a minute
A pathological condition caused by lack of oxygen, manifested in impending or actual cessation of life.
Mechanical or anoxic trauma incurred by the infant during labor or delivery.

A sudden, nonconvulsive loss of neurologic function due to an ischemic or hemorrhagic intracranial vascular event. In general, cerebrovascular accidents are classified by anatomic location in the brain, vascular distribution, etiology, age of the affected individual, and hemorrhagic vs. nonhemorrhagic nature. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, pp777-810)
A chronic infection of the conjunctiva and cornea caused by CHLAMYDIA TRACHOMATIS.
Tuberculosis of the lungs.
Tumors or cancer of the COLON.

An acute infectious disease caused by YERSINIA PESTIS that affects humans, wild rodents, and their ectoparasites. This condition persists due to its firm entrenchment in sylvatic rodent-flea ecosystems throughout the world. Bubonic plague is the most common form.

A transient unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs between the second and fifth days of life because the hepatic enzyme GLUCURONOSYLTRANSFERASE required for BILIRUBIN detoxification is inadquedate.
Tumors or cancer of the breast.

A disease caused by any of a number of species of protozoa in the genus LEISHMANIA. There are four major clinical types of this infection: cutaneous (Old and New World) (LEISHMANIASIS, CUTANEOUS), diffuse cutaneous (LEISHMANIASIS, DIFFUSE CUTANEOUS), mucocutaneous (LEISHMANIASIS, MUCOCUTANEOUS), and visceral (LEISHMANIASIS, VISCERAL).

A disorder of cardiac function caused by insufficient blood flow to the muscle tissue of the heart. The decreased blood flow may be due to narrowing of the coronary arteries (CORONARY ARTERIOSCLEROSIS), to obstruction by a thrombus (CORONARY THROMBOSIS), or less commonly, to diffuse narrowing of arterioles and other small vessels within the heart. Severe interruption of the blood supply to the myocardial tissue may result in necrosis of cardiac muscle (MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION).
Bites and stings inflicted by insects.
A circumscribed collection of fluid, especially a collection of fluid in the tunica vaginalis of the testicle or along the spermatic cord. (Dorland, 27th ed)

A condition in which the sense of hearing, although defective, is functional with or without a hearing aid. The hearing loss may affect one or both ears. The normal hearing level for speech is approximately 40-70 decibels I.S.O. (International Organization for Standardization) or 30-60 db A.S.A. (American Standards Association).
A disease characterized by chronic hemolytic anemia, episodic painful crises, and pathologic involvement of many organs. It is the clinical expression of homozygosity for hemoglobin S.

An ocular disease, occurring in many forms, having as its primary characteristics an unstable or a sustained increase in the intraocular pressure which the eye cannot withstand without damage to its structure or impairment of its function. The consequences of the increased pressure may be manifested in a variety of symptoms, depending upon type and severity, such as excavation of the optic disk, hardness of the eyeball, corneal anesthesia, reduced visual acuity, seeing of colored halos around lights, disturbed dark adaptation, visual field defects, and headaches. (Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed)
Illegitimate use of drugs for a desired effect in humans or animals. Not specified whether use is episodic, chronic, or in remission.
Deviations from the average or standard indices of refraction of the eye through its dioptric or refractive apparatus.
DEF: Disease of the cardiovascular system, that is, the heart and blood vessels.
A heterogeneous group of disorders that share glucose intolerance in common.
A major affective disorder marked by severe mood swings (manic or major depressive episodes) and a tendency to remission and recurrence.
Disorders in which anxiety (persistent feelings of apprehension, tension, or uneasiness) is the predominant disturbance.

A primary, chronic disease with genetic, psychosocial, and environmental factors influencing its development and manifestations. The disease is often progressive and fatal. It is characterized by impaired control over drinking, preoccupation with the drug alcohol, use of alcohol despite adverse consequences, and distortions in thinking, most notably denial. Each of these symptoms may be continuous or periodic. (Morse & Flavin for the Joint Commission of the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence and the American Society of Addiction Medicine to Study the Definition and Criteria for the Diagnosis of Alcoholism: in JAMA 1992;268:1012-4)
kupiga vita pombe

A group of viral diseases of diverse etiology but having many similar clinical characteristics; increased capillary permeability, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia are common to all. Hemorrhagic fevers are characterized by sudden onset, fever, headache, generalized myalgia, backache, conjunctivitis, and severe prostration, followed by various hemorrhagic symptoms. Hemorrhagic fever with kidney involvement is HEMORRHAGIC FEVER WITH RENAL SYNDROME.
Schistosomiasis caused by SCHISTOSOMA HAEMATOBIUM. It is endemic in Africa and parts of the Middle East, and affects the urinary tract.
The condition of having been bitten by a snake (not specified if venomous or non-venomous), characterized by stinging pain at the wound puncture.
Tumors or cancer of the LUNG.
Acute conjunctival inflammation in the newborn, usually caused by maternal gonococcal infection. The baby's eyes are contaminated during passage through the birth canal.
Edema due to obstruction of lymph vessels or disorders of the lymph nodes.

Primary carcinoma of the liver cells. It ranges from a well-differentiated tumor difficult to distinguish from normal hepatocytes to a poorly differentiated neoplasm. The cells may be uniform or markedly pleomorphic or may form giant cells. Several classification schemes have been suggested.
Schistosomiasis caused by Schistosoma mansoni. It is endemic in Africa, the Middle East, South America, and the Caribbean and affects mainly the bowel, spleen, and liver.
Infection with nematodes of the genus ONCHOCERCA. Characteristics include the presence of firm subcutaneous nodules filled with adult worms, pruritus, and ocular lesions.
A genus of nematode parasites which inhabit the body cavity, serous membranes, and connective tissues of vertebrates. The species parasitic in man is Dracunculus medinensis.
Heart decompensation in which the heart is unable to maintain adequate circulation of blood in the tissues of the body or to pump out the venous blood returned to it by the venous circulation.

Retinopathy associated with diabetes mellitus, which may be of the background type, progressively characterized by microaneurysms, interretinal punctuate macular edema, or of the proliferative type, characterized by neovascularization of the retina and optic disk, which may project into the vitreous, proliferation of fibrous tissue, vitreous hemorrhage, and retinal detachment.
Tumors or cancer of the prostate.

The inability to see or the loss or absence of perception of visual stimuli. This condition may be the result of EYE DISEASES; OPTIC NERVE DISEASES; OPTIC CHIASM diseases; or BRAIN DISEASES affecting the VISUAL PATHWAYS or OCCIPITAL LOBE.

A disease endemic among people and animals in Central Africa. It is caused by various species of trypanosomes, particularly T. gambiense and T. rhodesiense. Its second host is the tsetse fly. Involvement of the central nervous system produces "African sleeping sickness." Nagana is a rapidly fatal trypanosomiasis of horses and other animals.
DEF: Frequent and loose bowel movements of acute onset (< 24 hours). DESC: Commonly associated with abdominal pain. May be associated with blood or mucus in the stool. REF: URL
A baby who was born before 37 weeks of gestation.
Diagnoses for the baby born with complication

Visual impairments limiting one or more of the basic functions of the eye: visual acuity, dark adaptation, color vision, or peripheral vision. These may result from EYE DISEASES; OPTIC NERVE DISEASES; VISUAL PATHWAY diseases; OCCIPITAL LOBE diseases; OCULAR MOTILITY DISORDERS; and other conditions. Visual disability refers to inability of the individual to perform specific visual tasks, such as reading, writing, orientation, or traveling unaided. (From Newell, Ophthalmology: Principles and Concepts, 7th ed, p132)

Conditions characterized by language abilities (comprehension and expression of speech and writing) that are below the expected level for a given age, generally in the absence of an intellectual impairment. These conditions may be associated with DEAFNESS; BRAIN DISEASES; MENTAL DISORDERS; or environmental factors.
Convenient Set whose members are OPD Diagnoses

Accidents on streets, roads, and highways involving drivers, passengers, pedestrians, or vehicles. Traffic accidents refer to AUTOMOBILES (passenger cars, buses, and trucks), BICYCLING, and MOTORCYCLES but not OFF-ROAD MOTOR VEHICLES, RAILROADS nor snowmobiles.
Infections of newborns that occur shortly after birth, presumably due to issues related to delivery.
A list of HMIS 105 outpatient diagnosis
Kind of malaria test done
Results from the malaria test done
Is patient linked to the TB clinic or treatment after diagnosed with TB.
The referral number given to a patient when first referred to current facility
does patient need palliative care.
Tumors or cancer of the MOUTH.
Tumors or cancer of the MOUTH.

A recurrent disease of the oral mucosa of unknown etiology. It is characterized by small white ulcerative lesions, single or multiple, round or oval. Two to eight crops of lesions occur per year, lasting for 7 to 14 days and then heal without scarring. (From Jablonski's Dictionary of Dentistry, 1992, p742)

A recurrent disease of the oral mucosa of unknown etiology. It is characterized by small white ulcerative lesions, single or multiple, round or oval. Two to eight crops of lesions occur per year, lasting for 7 to 14 days and then heal without scarring. (From Jablonski's Dictionary of Dentistry, 1992, p742)

A recurrent disease of the oral mucosa of unknown etiology. It is characterized by small white ulcerative lesions, single or multiple, round or oval. Two to eight crops of lesions occur per year, lasting for 7 to 14 days and then heal without scarring. (From Jablonski's Dictionary of Dentistry, 1992, p742)
other gender
Occupations not available in coded lists

Social Network Strategy (SNS) is an evidence-supported approach to engage and motivate a person to accept HIV testing. This approach is based on the underlying principle that persons within the same social network who know, trust, and can exert influence on each other share similar HIV risk behaviors. SNS is particularly useful to recruit marginalized and/or hidden persons at risk for HIV.
